thread.title: European stocks mixed on China slowdown
thread.title_full: European stocks mixed on China slowdown

title: European stocks mixed on China slowdown
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 19, 2015, 15:35 BST - UK Markets close in 55 mins. European stocks mixed on China slowdown AFP â€“ 27 minutes ago View Photo 

Europe's main stock markets were mixed Monday on Chinese stimulus hopes following news that China's economy grew in the third quarter at its slowest pace for six years. 
China's powerhouse economy expanded by 6.9 percent in July-September, the weakest since 2009 at the height of the global recession, the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS) said. 
At the same time, the outcome beat market expectations of 6.8-percent expansion, according to analysts polled by AFP. 
London's benchmark FTSE 100 index was off 0.55 percent at 6,366.80 points in afternoon trading as it emerged Chinese industrial production rose just 5.7 percent year-on-year in September, missing economists? median estimate of 6.0 percent. 
In the eurozone, the Paris CAC 40 was down 0.23 percent, reversing earlier gains, at 4,690.86 with ArcelorMittel -- the world's biggest steelmaker -- off 1.56 percent to 5.547 euros. 
Frankfurt's DAX 30 index in contrast was up 0.27 percent to stand at 10,132.21 points some two hours before the close. 
US stocks meanwhile opened weaker on Chinese data and some disappointing earnings. 
"Pressure will be ramping up on Beijing to implement more economic stimulus," said analyst Augustin Eden at trading firm Accendo Markets. 
In New York just after the opening bell, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was at 17,156.58, down 0.34 percent, while the broad-based S&P 500 fell 0.37 percent to 2,025.65. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.23 percent to 4,875.55. 
- Miners struggle - 
The news from Beijing pulled London lower as the British capital's mining sector is heavily reliant on demand from top commodity consumer China. 
In reaction, commodity giant Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) saw its share price dive 3.97 percent mid-afternoon to 111.40 pence, BHP Billiton (NYSE: BBL - news ) shed 2.39 percent to 1,102.50 pence and Rio Tinto (LSE: RIO.L - news ) lost 1.99 percent to 2,443 pence. 
"Whilst the eurozone indices have shaken off the morning?s Chinese data dump, the FTSE is struggling in the face of the country?s manufacturing slowdown," said analyst Connor Campbell at trading firm Spreadex. 
"With ... commodity stocks in general clogging up the morning's losers list, the FTSE is straggling behind its eurozone peers, flip-flopping between mild losses and even milder gains as investors try (and fail) to search for some sense of firm direction." 
The Chinese GDP data is the first official confirmation of investors' fears over growth in the world's number two economy and follows a string of weak indicators including on trade and manufacturing activity. 
The economy is forecast to grow this year at a slower pace than last year's 7.3 percent, the worst annual rate in almost a quarter of a century. 
In Asian equity trade on Monday, Shanghai rose almost one percent straight after the GDP data release on hopes for fresh stimulus but eventually ended the day 0.14 percent lower amid a general regional retreat. 
Global indices were sent into freefall in August -- wiping trillions of dollars off valuations -- when Beijing announced a shock devaluation of its yuan currency, which fuelled fears about the economy and leaders' grip on the crisis. 
In foreign exchange activity on Monday, the European single currency stood $1.1332 just off its $1.1363 finish Friday in New York.
